Dialogue.NPCText:
A wiry man is half-buried beneath the hull of a strange, half-built vessel. Smoke curls from wild silver hair; his apron bristles with tools and broken crystal shards. He bolts upright at your approach, eyes gleaming.

"You! Are you here to rob me, ridicule me, or rescue me? Bah—never mind! Unless you’re with those blasted thugs, step lively, there’s work to be done and wonders to be made."

Edrin Ashvine, famed shipwright and untamed inventor, grins and gestures you closer.

Option.text: I heard you needed help. What's troubling you?
You’re Edrin Ashvine, the airship inventor?
Tell me your story, Ashvine. What makes you tick?

Dialogue.NPCText:
Edrin waves a wrench angrily.
"Trouble? Try sabotage! Rival merchants send ruffians to wreck my workshop, steal my plans, break my prototypes! I’m this close to flying the first *Crystalwind Galleon* over Sunreach, but I need materials, muscle, and a smidge of coin."

"Will you help an old dreamer outsmart these groundbound jackals?"

He puffs his chest.
"Edrin Ashvine—formerly of Jhelom’s shipyards, now Sunreach’s only certified Airshipwright. I tamed sails and storms, then partnered with Captain Rhogar—before he went all piratey, the daft lout. Now? I build wonders with Aria Silverhand—she brings me Aerilon’s floating crystals, I give her secrets of hull and timber. Together, we might just keep Sunreach above water… and above betrayal."

He winks. "Got questions? Or ready to get your hands dirty?"

"Brilliant, secretive, and far too brave for her own good. Aria knows more about Aerilon’s magic than most mages, and more about Sunreach’s underbelly than most cutthroats. She brings me blue crystals and maps to forgotten ruins. If you run into her, tell her the stabilizers are nearly finished… and to watch her back."

Edrin sighs.
"Rhogar and I built ships together, once. He was a genius with a rudder, better with a broadsword. After the pirates came, he picked their side—said the council was rotten. Can’t blame him, not entirely, but I miss the days when our arguments were over wind angles, not blood money."
"He’d still help me if I asked. Maybe you can convince him."

Option.text: I’ll leave you to your work.

Dialogue.NPCText:
He drags you to a half-finished airship.
"Behold! The *Crystalwind Galleon*. With Aerilon’s floating crystal tech and Sunreach’s finest hulls, she’ll fly over sea and sand alike! Or she would, if rival houses didn’t keep sending brutes to smash the crystals or swipe my schematics."

"Help me finish her, and Sunreach might just out-soar Minax herself."

Option.text: This is all above my pay grade.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Edrin spits.
"The Ashveil Corsairs, House Veynar’s cronies, maybe even Qasarian spies—everyone wants my secrets or to see me fail. I trust only Aria and a handful of honest laborers. If you see anyone skulking near my workshop, give them a whack for me."
"But best way to stop the sabotage? Get the last stabilizer crystal from Aria before they do. That, and a little muscle to guard my shop tonight."

Option.text: What do you need from me, exactly?
I’m not the muscle you need.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Edrin’s eyes light up with hope.
"Three tasks, if you’re willing!
  • Fetch the last stabilizer crystal from Aria Silverhand—she’s hiding near the old amphitheater.
  • Guard my workshop tonight against saboteurs. Expect thugs—armed, desperate, and possibly on Minax’s payroll.
  • IF you’ve got deep pockets, a little funding never hurts. I need 2,500 gold to finish the galleon’s core rigging."
"Do one, two, or all three—I’ll reward you as only a true inventor can!"

Option.text: I’ll find Aria and bring you the crystal.
Here is 2,500 gold to fund your work.
Can you pay me in advance?
That’s too much for me right now.

Dialogue.NPCText:
"Bring me the stabilizer crystal and don’t let anyone see you with it—Minax’s spies watch everywhere!
When you return, I’ll show you something even Aerilon’s archmages haven’t seen."
"Meet me at the workshop after sundown. I’ll have a cudgel and a cask of my strongest brew waiting—nothing like a good brawl to keep the mind sharp!"

Edrin’s eyes widen at the pouch.
"Bless the winds! This’ll buy enough quicksilver and gears to finish the core. Take this—an experimental airship cog, finely balanced. If you ever get your hands on an airship hull, you’ll want this."

Edrin cackles.
"Advance? The first rule of invention—never trust a stranger with your coin! But do well, and you’ll get a reward fit for a sky-captain."

Option.text: Fair enough. I’ll get to work.

Dialogue.NPCText: Edrin shrugs and dives back under his airship hull, muttering about fools, pirates, and lost dreams.

Option.text: Wait, I changed my mind. Do you need help?
I’ll leave you to your work.

Dialogue.NPCText:
Edrin taps his temple, then slaps the hull of his airship like an old friend.

“Ahhh, the inner workings! Of the man *and* the machine. You’ve got curiosity—I like that. Let's play a game. Ask a question, any question. I’ll answer—truthfully, mostly—and maybe toss in a gift for a keen listener.”

He leans in with a grin. “But beware, some answers come with *side effects*...”

Option.text: What drives you to build airships?

Dialogue.NPCText:
“Because the sea betrayed me,” he says with a shrug. “My first ship—*The Brine Vow*—was swallowed in a typhoon shaped like a woman’s eye. I washed up in Aerilon with a cracked rib and a crazed idea: *if water kills dreams, put ‘em in the sky.*”

“And I tell you—clouds never lie. Storms kill, yes, but they don’t lie.”

He hands you something.
“For asking the right question.”

“Because muscle outweighed mind. Jhelom’s council never understood invention—just warships, bigger cannons, louder warcries. They laughed at my gyroscopic sail rigs, called them ‘spinny death fans’. Hah!”

He raises an eyebrow.
“They weren’t wrong… at first. But now I’ve got fans that hover, pivot, *slice* if needed.”

You feel slightly smarter for hearing him explain it.

Edrin’s eyes lose focus.
“There was a woman once, dressed like dusk and smelling like ozone. She asked about floating cores and offered a ‘dream engine’ in return.”
He shivers. “I woke up a week later with no memory, my beard braided into propellers.”

“If that was Minax, she’s not just evil—she’s inventive. And I hate that I admire that.”

He passes you a strange part.
“Found this wedged in my ribs after. Maybe you’ll have better luck.”

Edrin chuckles, then grows still.
“I miss the idiot, aye. He once built a raft out of shark carcasses and *sailed it into a hurricane to impress a barmaid.* He came back with treasure and three broken ribs.”

He lowers his voice.
“Last I heard, he’s in a power struggle with that she-devil Seraphine. If you ever see him… tell him I still have the sky anchor we built.”

You feel a strange nostalgia…

Edrin smirks and salutes you with a wrench.
“Fine taste in small talk. I’ll be here—hammering dreams into rivets and whispering secrets into sails.”
